I was so scared of chemo, but I am now looking at it as my personal insurance policy and a way for me to feel more relaxed moving forward that I have dome everything that I can to avoid recurrence. It's only a few weeks of my life, and I will get through it! It's been enormously helpful to read other women's stories here. I also got in touch with the ACS Reach for Recovery people, and was contacted yesterday by a woman diagnosed 8 years ago with almost the exact same profile, age, etc who did chemo. Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2012 10:29PM ckk wrote: Bailey and Momof3, I'll be thinking of you all day and hope that your infusions go well. Regarding bitchiness: I'm really bitchy in general these days. My patience has left the building with everyone except my kids. I'm interpreting it as overload - too much stress, too much discomfort, too much fear. There's only so much one person can handle at once. I know that the people around me are surprised, because that's just not me. But this is short lived, I guess.They'll live and maybe learn something about compassion. I don't buy into the "big pharma is blocking a cure" stuff. There's just too many countries and universities doing research, too many people with their hands on breast cancer research to keep a cure under wraps. I just think that cancer is a very complicated disease (set of diseases, really) that we don't understand yet. If you look on this board, you see a variety of different cancers that are all called breast cancer - IDC, ILC, DCIS, etc, and then different hormone receptor statuses. I know that the approach to BC care keeps changing dramatically because of research. Many of us would have received Adriamycin just a few years ago, but do not now because of studies that show Taxotere is just as effective with fewer long term risks.  This is day 7 for me, so theoretically my lowest count day. I am hoping that it's all better from here. I still have heart pounding and extreme fatigue. I'm going to lay low today, maybe make some bread and work from home. My vein is still red but seems less sore today, which is good. Hugs to all! This is my favorite spot on the Internet, gals.

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2012 10:28PM ckk wrote: Happy weekend all! I pretty much threw the kitchen sink at my neuropathy symptoms over the last couple of days - went to the chiropractor, who said that misalignment can exacerbate neuropathy symptoms, and also had acupuncture. The AC gave me a Vitamin B12 shot too. The nurse in the MO office also suggested keeping my hands and feet warm (it's cold here) and wearing slippers around the house to cushion my feet. I do feel much better today; the tingling has stopped. I am feeling pretty normal - worked out yesterday, did errands. I guess that I'll spend the next few days before #3 cooking ahead and trying to feel normal before the next tidal wave. Gracie-I have gained a bit of weight also, and my MO also said that it's from the Taxotere and should resolve after treatment ends. Yet another "gift" of chemo, ugh. momof3boys- I'm so sorry that you're feeling lousy. I also felt tired more quickly after no. 2. I just roll my eyes when people want to high-five me for being half way there. Really? Sometimes I think that it's worse being here because we KNOW what's ahead - more crud. rachel- I hear you about the chemo brain! I have major short term memory loss, and sometimes I can't find the right word to say. It's very frustrating, and yes, at times embarrassing. Hang in there, because I understand that it resolves pretty quickly after chemo (within a few months). Annie- we're with you, and understand the "I look okay on the outside but I'm a hot mess on the inside" stuff. If I hear one more person say how great I'm doing and how "inspirational" I am, I'm gonna lose it. You're right, this is the place to vent and swear and cry and bitch. Cancer sucks, dammit, and this ordeal is one that no one can understand unless they've lived it. Lisa- my cold cap buddy - using these things is a double-edged sword. We did it because we want to retain our privacy and some normalcy during cancer treatment, but the down side is that people tend to think of us as not going through much of anything. I think that it's very tough for people to acknowledge other people's pain - it's scary and uncomfortable - and we help them avoid that discomfort by not obviously looking like a cancer patient. But the SEs are just as bad, and we're suffering just as much. I know that you can sail through this last treatment with flying colors! You're a cold cap champ by now,and probably the first CC user at your infusion center, which means that you've given other women a gift of knowledge through showing  the nurses and doctors your success. heatherb8 and Madison - almost done! I can't wait until we're all on the other side and checking in to say hi. I hope that everyone has a good weekend, and thank you all again for the wonderful support here. This place is my haven and my life line.

She discouraged me from drinking in general, and during chemo in particular. She thought that it put too much strain on the liver during treatment. My current MO has talked to me about avoiding raw fish, raw vegetables, raw fruits that are not peeled (peeled ones are ok), unpasteurized items, and - this one she mentions every time that I see her - don't eat off of anyone else's plate. lol   Josie, the FB group is secret. Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2012 10:10AM ckk wrote: Karen, I have also been very concerned about chemo brain, as some things, particularly my word retrieval ability, have suffered since being dx'd. I got a book from Amazon - "Your Brain After Chemo, a Practical Guide to Lifting the fog and getting back your focus", by Dan Silverman. It's a really interesting book. The first part goes into detail about the physiological changes in your brain from chemo, and then the second half quotes studies and gives suggestions as to how to get brain function back to normal. Believe it or not, the most helpful thing suggested so far for me has been to ingest more caffeine - it really helps with the word retrieval issues. I am really motivated to come out of this and recover - get back my strength, my mental focus, and my energy. Don't be hard on yourself, though. It will take time to come back, but we can all do it!

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2012 12:42AM ckk wrote: Bailey, congrats on the new addition! Did you decide on the name? I too am having whole-breast irradiation for 28 doses, then 5 "boosts" of the lumpectomy region. They are not doing my node area because the tumor site was very close to the node. Interesting what your RO said about knowing that you'll have skin issues. I was told by my RO that they used to think that they could predict who would have trouble based upon skin color, etc, but they found that really couldn't. Did they tell you to put cream on the breast before and during treatment? I am supposed to start using a cream that contains both aloe & vitamin E 2x/day two weeks before treatment starts, and then all during treatment. They gave me a bunch of samples to try, and I have decided to use "Jeans Cream", which was available at my local natural pharmacy. It was apparently created by a BC survivor after she had skin problems during rads. heatherb8, hope your fatigue lets up soon. karmil, are you doing anything to alleviate the hot flashes, or did they ease up on their own? I need help! Wave, I'm so glad to hear that you've started to feel good! I'm sure that your family understood your challenges, and I can relate to your unhappiness about the fatigue. Lisa, so good to hear that you're feeling better re:SEs! Yay on the new hair growth! robin309, I was so touched to read about your time with your daughter. I too have drawn great comfort and solace from my two daughters, and this experience has brought us closer. I was initially very worried about how this would affect them, but they have come through like champs. Good for you for getting through your challenging day. Rachel, your pace is so challenging, and I'm glad to hear that you're resting a bit. You've been through so much, and it's okay to rest and recuperate for a time. Regarding looking old: we have all gone through a tremendous amount of physical & emotional turmoil in a short period of time -  the diagnosis, surgery, chemo, etc. The fact that we're wearing it on our faces right now is no surprise, but it will NOT last forever. We will emerge stronger and more beautiful when this is over, ladies. You are all incredibly resilient and beautiful people, and that will shine through when this is done! I woke up to discover new eyebrow and eyelash hairs growing! I've been using Latisse for a short while, and didn't expect to see anything so soon, but there they were. My arm is better today, not as red or painful. I have a nadir visit with my MO tomorrow, and I plan to ask about the taxotere issue. Have a good Sunday!

The first MO that I consulted at Dana Farber was technically brilliant, authored studies, etc., but had no warmth or caring for me as a patient. My local MO is exactly the opposite. Yay for being halfway done! How is your skin doing? Any pain? Leesa, if you do consult a personal trainer, make sure that they are aware of and know how to train you to minimize lymphedema risk. If they are ACSM certified, there are materials available through ACSM that they can draw upon to make sure that you work out safely. The ACSM web site has a list of certified cancer trainers on their site:  http://members.acsm.org/source/custom/Online_locator/OnlineLocator.cfm Wave, I was a WW leader for 15 years, and did two meetings per week in the evening. The program works, and I still follow the guidelines. It's medically safe and I recommend it highly. I asked my Rad ctr about weight loss during rads, and they said no worries, that thay rescan and recalibrate every 10 sessions, and that people lose their cancer weight all of the time through rad treatment.You may want to ask yours about it too. As for the hair...it's funny, we're both trapped by the hair situation. I feel incredibly self conscious when I'm out and about or with friends. Women stare at my head when they talk to me, and strangers give me arrogant, contemptuous looks (as in, why can't she take care of herself?). I know that it will pass and I'm glad that I did the caps, but it's hard right now. Hopefully my rad center will be up and running again today! Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2011 08:35AM ckk wrote: Wave, I am sending you a hug. I had a similar meltdown this morning with my H. I was trying to describe to him what this feels like (flu x 100?), but words just didn't do it. Let me tell you what I've been doing for my crabby stomach, and perhaps it will help you. I don't have any large meals, and as soon as I feel ONE twinge of discomfort or hunger, I eat something small - a few pieces of cantaloupe, a bit of yogurt, some cheese, whatever appeals at the moment. I think that my cramping, nausea and pain issues are from excessive stomach acid. I am on an acid blocker (prilosec) 2 x day, and I'm supplementing with Mylanta. This morning I was pokey about going down to the kitchen to get something to eat, and it started a tidal wave of stomach problems. I forced myself to eat something and that settled things right down. If you're having diarrhea, you need to make sure that you're drinking enough, and maybe try the BRAT diet (bananas, rice, applesauce, toast). Can you try a flavored water, or spritz some lemon juice into your water? Also, ginger green tea might be appealing and soothing. I am determined to get out today and move, because I want to see if that helps. I also was formerly very active - biking, weight training, etc., and it feels lousy to sit on my ass.  Good luck with your appt today!

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2012 05:46PM ckk wrote: Hi Ladies! As you can see, the steroids are doing their work, because here I am, fresh as a daisy at 1:30 am. I fell asleep early in the evening from all of the ativan, only to wake up.  But, I'M DONE! The infusion was with one exception the easiest yet, I'm glad to say. The IV went in smoothly the first time thank goodness. I had the same nurse that I've had 3 of the 4 infusions, so she was well versed in the cold cap regimen. The caps have caused quite a stir in my chemo center as no one has seen anyone use them before, or keep their hair through this treatment. The infusion center head nurse came over and and asked questions, observed the caps being put on, and I spoke with her regarding the center getting a donated freezer from the Rapunzel project to help patients using the caps (they wouldn't have to use dry ice or coolers). I'll go back when I'm better and talk to her about it. Anyway, my nurse started the day by bringing over a pink boa and pink cowboy hat for me to wear to mark my last time! The infusion went smoothly. We are having a real warm snap here, temp in the high 50s, so H bought extra dry ice just in case since we buy it the night before tx. Because of this, the caps came out of the coolers MUCH COLDER than usual, -50 degrees in some spots, and took a long time to warm up. I know that most of the caps went on my head colder than -32,and that first cap was brutal. I had had ativan in my premeds, and that formerly was enough to get me over the first 5 minutes of pain, but I was seriously hurting enough to ask for more ativan. Nurse said that I'd had the max and started to look into other options, but a few minutes later my scalp froze and I was fine for the rest of the day. After that, no problems at all and finished with a fast saline flush in hopes to avoid plebitis. The infusion center nurses came over at the end of the tx and stood around and clapped and hugged me for finishing! There I was, cold cap on my head, shivering, weepy, exhausted, but I felt great! Too funny. We took lots of pics and I'll post some on FB. Then home, and 4 more hours of caps. I took another ativan and zonked out on the chair, woke up to eat pizza before the taste buds bid farewell, and then zonked out again for a bit. Now, I fear that I'm up and on the roller coaster yet again. Crud days, here I come! I see the MO again on the 6th for a nadir visit and will ask all of the fantastic follow up questions you ladies suggest. My breast MRI is scheduled the week of the 12th. I have my mapping that week, too, and start rads on the 19th.  Gracie, so glad that you're feeling good, and I love your attitude about how we are all getting stronger and will get better on the other side! I have the SAME intentions. I will be fighting to get back to stronger, more energetic, and healthier. I bought a book to use with my trainer called "The Breast Cancer's Survivor's Fitness Plan",  by Carolyn Kaelin, an MD, and three ACE certified cancer trainers. It has specific stretching and strength exercises for BC survivors, and a whole chapter on safely working out with lymphedema, or alternatively, how to avoid lymphedema.  heatherb8, sorry to hear about your hand! Be careful and watch it for infection. I read somewhere that we have to careful of that. Bailey, sorry to hear about your tingling. Excuse my chemo brain - did you try AC? Mine also gives me a B12 shot every time that I go. I have one treatment the day after TX, and one 2 weeks later. They work! Lisa, I wonder if you can ask to be transferred to a more sedentary set of responsibilities for half of your day over the next few months? I feel so bad that you are struggling through your day this way. Can you talk to your boss about it, let them know what you're going through? It IS only temporary. Rachel, glad that the thrush is better! Whew, thank goodness that you avoided the Noro virus. I sat with friends at the jazz concert the other night who had just had it the week before, and it sounded horrific, truly. I hope that you continue to improve, and that your leg gets better. Wave, your list of chemo SEs should be put on index cards and given out to every well meaning soul who compares chemo to the flu.Can I add phlebitis? I hope that you take it easy during this down time, and maybe get out a bit each day to stretch and do a few steps.  robin309, good for you for getting on that treadmill!  momof3, my MO also said that bone pain is common on this regimen. She said that eating adequate protein would help it ease over time, and that it would ease up. Karen, I hope that your sore throat is better today. It's your circle-the-wagons week, so hopefully rest and fluids will kick it out. I hear you on the hot flashes. My girl friend has a remote control fan in her bedroom - what a great idea! Where do I get one? Well, I'm off to my chair to ice down my infusion site in hopes to avoid phlebitis on this last one. Oh, and drink a gallon of water to get rid of the chemo. OH, AND send back the damn cold caps tomorrow! WHOOOOOOOOO! Have a great day all! I am so grateful to all of you! I wish that I could give you all hugs and hope that we truly can meet when we're recovered.

Rachel, your post made me teary, and I so wish that I could give you a hug, and I would really like to kick your BC friend's ass for writing what she did about recovery. Recovery is lots of things: physical, emotional, and psychological. You can tell by just a casual read of this site that we all recover at different rates. It matters what shape you were in going into it, how you've taken care of yourself during tx, and your support system. I firmly believe that the people we surround ourselves with make a big difference to our recovery. A cancer diagnosis is a great sifter and vacuum cleaner. You deserve to limit your interactions to people who lift you up, not bring you down. You have behaved like a survivor through ALL of this, so that's the way you will act moving forward. It's okay to be angry with people who don't get it, and it's okay to keep explaining it to them until they do. When my family was suffering from the stomach flu over the weekend, weak and achy and nauseous, I told them that THAT was somewhat what chemo after-effects felt like, but multiplied by 100 or so. It seemed to light the bulb over their heads. In the end, no one except a fellow survivor is going to know and understand the struggle and eventual triumph that we face. You are not done with treatment...trust us, it will get better! Gracie, good luck with your upcoming surgery. Leesa, I've decided to be zen about the grey hair thing. Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2011 04:22PM ckk wrote: Lisa, I also had LVI at my tumor site with negative nodes, and was also very depressed and concerned. The two oncologists that I spoke to about it said that lymph node involvement and HER2 status are much more indicative of longer term prognosis, and that the jury is still out on the role that LVI plays. Doing chemo is apparently the best defense against cancer cells roaming about looking for a home. In addition, your Oncotype score is supposed to be a good predictor, too, and again, the chemo plus tamoxifen brings that recurrence rate down. I think that all of us will now have to deal with this new reality of looking over our shoulder. I was diagnosed with malignant melanoma 12 years ago, so I can tell you that while that deep fear is intense at the beginning, it does fade in time.Eventually it hardens into an old scab that scratches off and bleeds briefly when you have a follow up scan or test. But it does get better. In any case, I think that talking to someone is good.

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2012 05:55AM ckk wrote: Good morning ladies. It's been an interesting few days here. I struggled with fever all weekend, felt terrible, kept talking to the doctor, etc. trying to figure out what was going on. On Sunday, the shoe dropped. My husband discovered that oldest daughter had been sick with a sore throat since Thursday (my lowest WBC point) and hadn't said anything because she didn't want to worry me. She was still feeling lousy, so... simple test for you that you'll all pass with flying colors...kid is sick with a sore throat for 4 days, no other symptoms...guesses? BINGO! My H took her into Urgent Care and she was indeed positive for strep, so I had been immersed in a strep-infested environment at my lowest point for 4 days. Thank goodness that I was put on Augmentin proactively by my MO on Friday. I called the doc again, and she told me to go to the ER and get my blood count done. If it was still low, she wanted me admitted and on IV antibiotics and observed. The blood count was way up, thank goodness, and the fever down, so they sent me home after testing the other family members for strep also. They were all negative. H spent the next 24 hours wiping down all surfaces, knobs, etc with antibac wipes and washing linens, while I stayed in isolation in the bedroom. When the smoke cleared last night, we had a family meeting about what happened, how important it was for me to avoid pathogens during critical days in my treatment, and what to do if they felt ill. Lesson learned, hopefully. I'm feeling much better this morning - no fever, pretty energetic, and daughter seems to be on the mend, albeit a bit upset that BF had to go home :-).  He wasn't symptomatic, but given the way strep is passed along it was just too much risk to have him around possibly incubating a new case, putting me at risk for infection yet again. One of the hardest transitions for me has been to be a patient and thus need care from others, and to learn that I have to put myself first sometimes. Maybe that's not so bad? I'm hoping for at least one good week! Next infusion is on 1/12. Hope everyone is doing well.

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2012 03:59PM ckk wrote: Hi everyone. I want to add a comment about the recurrence fears that we all have. I think that I posted before that I'm a melanoma survivor. When I was diagnosed 12 years ago (at age 39), I got the %$^& scared out of me when I read the horror stories and was convinced that I would not see age 50. I did not listen to my doctor, who kept telling me that my prognosis was excellent, and my loved ones, who tried to keep me focused and positive. Well, here I am at age 51, trading melanoma stories with other people newly diagnosed and giving them hope. WE will be that person 10, 15, 20 years from now when our friends, colleagues, sisters, and daughters are diagnosed with this disease, telling them our story and giving them strength. We will be SURVIVORS who will emerge from this battle stronger, wiser, and more compassionate to those around us because we will intimately know suffering and fear. I read about all of your struggles, I think about mine, and I marvel that we all get up and face the next day with such courage. This disease takes so much from us and still we prevail, and indeed we triumph. We are here because we are smart, trying to educate and arm ourselves in the best way possible. How many times have you quoted something that you've learned here, and someone, maybe even a practitioner, has said "I didn't know that!".  My day has been much better today, probably equal to a normal day. I realized that even the smallest chores make me smile, because being able to do them is a victory! Who would have thought that cleaning the kitchen would be pleasurable? And, on a much better note, I ordered my spring seeds today! Any other gardeners out there?

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2012 12:10PM ckk wrote: Heather, my understanding re: cold caps & the brain is that it's not so much the brain as the scalp. There are certain systemic cancers such as leukemia that people should not use the caps, as it's important for the chemotherapy to reach as much of the body as possible. The chances of metastasis to the scalp in BC is pretty much nonexistent, far less so than lung, or bone. I spoke at length with both of the MOs that I consulted, and both had no problem with using them from a mets basis, although they were both skeptical that they worked at all. The caps are used pretty extensively in Europe (where they also covered by insurance), and there have been far more studies done there on long term use. I'm guessing that we will eventually see more studies here, especially since there was recently a clinical trial (maybe two) done in the U.S. on the road to getting approval here.

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2012 06:40AM ckk wrote: Hi Ladies. I am wiped today, with a fast heartbeat, so I know that my WBC is down down down. I am trying to lay low and ride it out. I called the MO office, and the nurse said to apply heat 20 minutes x 6 times or so today and watch for a temp. I really don't want an infection, dammit. Let's hope that I don't have to drag myself in there tomorrow. I can definitely relate to being impatient with people's reactions to what we go through. Maybe we should start a new thread - s&%$ people say when they know you're battling breast cancer? Here's my personal favorites (with my unsaid replies in parens lol): "It could always be worse, you know"  (you mean, if it was YOU?) "You are an inspiration"   (just don't say anything if you can't think of something, honey) "Please call me if you need anything"  (ok, can you stop pretending I don't exist? sheesh) "I hope that you know that I've been thinking about you"  (nope, not psychic) I think that most people mean well, but cancer brings out the TRUE in people. If they're givers, they continue to give, if they're takers, they relate everything back to themselves. It's hard to see these things when we're in a bad place, and I do think that it's fundamentally changed my perception of the world. I know that I will be a different person when this part of my journey ends, and maybe that's not a bad thing. I know that I'm naturally a giving person, and it was a shock to realize that I could not depend on some that I assumed would be there, even for emotional support. But this will make us all stronger, and wiser, I think. On the flip side, it's also produced some incredibly beautiful moments when I saw the kindness in some. Hope everyone's day is a good one. I am thankful for the honesty we have here!

It's written by a physician BC survivor and and exercise specialist, and has great stretches for different types of BC outcomes..lumpectomy, MX, etc. Jen, I'm with you on not relating to other people very well. I was at a concert last night at D's high school, saw lots of friends, and felt like an alien in the room. My whole life has been BC for 6 months, and I'm boring! lol Krmil, hope those geniuses can help with the computer. Wouldn't it be nice to have a title like "genius" at our jobs? hehe Wave, OMG, me too on the stinky underarms! It's been hot here, and I smell terrible. I go to the gym and apologize to my trainer, I apologize to my family...ugh. Hot flashes make it all worse. I didn't go to radiation today. The machine broke down and they canceled my appointment, so my tx's get pushed out one day. I went shopping with oldest D in preparation for her internship this summer, and I was exhausted by the time I got home. We went to an outlet mall one hour away...what a mistake! All that walking, plus driving. I felt really discouraged, thinking who is this overweight, tired, grey haired woman?? I'm telling you, I am determined to lose these 15 pounds, regain my strength, and color my hair soon. Maybe a nap first, though. Ugh.

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2012 10:05PM ckk wrote: Hey everyone..I haven't posted here in a bit...I've been catching up on things as my energy has been returning. I'm happy to say that I feel about 95% these days. I get tired at the very end of the day, but can last straight through without putting up my feet. I have to tell you that it feels very good to be back to myself! Melrose, welcome, and I'm very sorry that you had to join the club that noone wants to be in! At least you're in the company of the best women on the planet.  I seriously would not have been able to get through this without the company of these women. We have sustained each other through every stage of treatment and surgery, and where else can you find a 24-hour support group? As others have said,it would be a good idea for you to find or form a thread with others who are going through chemo at the same time. Your question re day of the week for chemo: I had my txs on Thursday, and in retrospect I wish that I had had them on Wednesday because day 4 was always my worst day. The first two days after chemo you're usually revved up on steroids, and then go downhill from there. Are you getting the neulasta shot? That will affect your progress, too. I did not receive neulasta at all through treatment, and because of that tried to stay close to home days 10-14 because of low counts. Wave, yay that you're almost done! Is hubby still in the Bahamas? Will you join him there soon? Bailey, I can so relate to your emotional moment! I have moments that I feel almost grateful for this bc (I know, crazy, right???) because I have seen and met such incredibly wonderful people in the journey. It's been easy to let go of the negative/unsupportive people in my life, and I am now left with the good ones! I feel like a better person too. I've met and made friends with two women this week who were recently dx'd, one who will be using the cold caps after seeing me with hair.  Don't ask me about this feeling of gratefulness tomorrow, though, when I'll be bitching and swearing again, lol. :-) Your rad center techs are awesome! Rachel, some input on moving when you're recovering from surgery. My melanoma surgery 12 years ago coincided exactly with moving out of one house to another. I couldn't change my closing date, and my derm said "no way" when asked if I could postpone the surgery. I was going to be on crutches and not allowed to lift anything or even keep the leg down for too long. I ended up calling a local moving company, explained my situation as a cancer patient, and they gave me a sizable break on moving (I packed by sitting on the floor while people handed me stuff). It pays to ask! Karmil,how's the Tamox going? I haven't been reading as much either. I think that my eyes have gotten worse since chemo, too. I need to have them checked. I have 16 more radiation txs to go, 8 whole breast, and 8 boosts. My skin looks a bit pink, and my nipples are now two different colors - one tan, one not, lol! My D thinks that's really awesome :-). I've held up well so far. The hot flashes and night sweats for some reason have come back with a vengeance this past couple of days...they had calmed down a bit after chemo.  I'm wondering if the ovaries are giving up for good? I hope so! I have a bone density test next week to establish a baseline before tamox, and I'm hoping that it's good. With all of the biking and weight training over the past few years, it had better be!  I hope that you all have a great weekend! I'm still cleaning out closets!

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2011 06:41AM ckk wrote: Hi everyone. Treatment #1 down. The infusion went very smoothly, no reactions at all. The IV went in smoothly, on the first try. I used the cold caps, and my nurse was fantastic about supporting me and my helpers. I had a migraine in the morning, which did not help, and it caused me to eat much less than I should have. By the time that I got home, I was very nauseous. I did ice my fingers and toes during the T portion, but didn't have ice in my mouth during that entire part of the infusion. I hope that doesn't get me into trouble. My nurse said that not everyone gets the mouth sores (even without icing), so to try not to worry. What with the cold caps, the icy cold feet and toes, and the cold moth, I was a very cold girl yesterday! The electric blanket that I brought was a lifesaver. I also wore my skiing base layer which was lined with thermal material. I didn't sleep much last night  - steroids, I guess. I'm nauseous again this morning, and took the acid blocker and steroid. I hope that they work. I also made some home made ginger tea that seems to be helping as I sit here and type. I have a question about one of the anti-nauseau meds I was prescribed, reglan. The bottle says that it may cause eye twitching. Has enyone taken this and had that reaction? Rachel - I hope that your tummy is better today, and good for you for getting back to work! Annie - I hope that you're better today and that work went well. Wave - My onc is on the fence about giving the neulasta shot automatically. I actually agreed to participate in a clinical study yesterday (sponsored by the makers of neulasta) that will help to predict which patients may benefit most from automatic shots between treatments. The study is not double-blind, but is using historical patient data. Josie - I hope that you are still feeling good. I was also the youngest person in my infusion suite. I guess that those of us in our 40s and 50s with earlier stage BC are getting chemotherapy pretty much across the board these days. If you look at the Oncotype statistics, you can see why the docs are giving us this recommendation. My Onc calls it my "cancer vacccine"! Heathrer - i hear you about finding an onc close by. My original Dr was in boston, about an hour away. After my surgery, I found an oncologist 5 minutes away who I love. It makes a big difference to go down the street for those infusions! Thanks to all of you for sharing your stories and offering encouragement. You are all helping others tremendously. I hope that everyone's holidays are joyful.

What I think that  it comes down to is that we each need to decide how we want our donation dollars spent and then find out which organizations fulfill that charter.  Lisa - did you call your MO? Annie, I'm up for us all meeting anywhere after all of this mess is done. Gracie - I was given the choice of T/C or A/C, with the comment that A can cause heart problems. Chemo was recommended to me despite clear nodes because I had a high grade tumor and LVI, and the thinking is that you need to hit BC hard and fast to deter recurrence. Both MOs that I consulted didn't care what my Onco score would be, and chose the regimens that they did because of clinical success. My understanding is that these chemo drugs are pretty standard for BC, and what differs is no. of treatments and whether you need to add Herceptin (if you're HER2+). But I may be simplifying things - please anyone else chime in if you have more info. loulabell - I can relate to doing too much and regretting it. Just doing laundry is wearing me out today! Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2012 05:41AM ckk wrote: Annie, I'm really glad that she's going home. She's still infectious for another 24 hours, and your immunity is on the down shift. This is the ONE time in our lives that we have to be selfish, hon. I swear by the antibacterial wipes, and use them every day around here. The joke is that if it's my down week, someone is sick! After the strep episode, I have not caught anything, despite H coming down with bronchitis after round 2. Keep an eye on that temp! And wash her linens in HOT water.  Rachel, regarding soy: I was advised by my MO to take it off the menu. When I started looking at labels, I was surprised at how many foods have soybean oil, and many generic vegetable oils are soybean, or soybean oil blends. And no edamame, darn it. Josie, I have also replaced all of my teflon pans with stainless steel. Costco sells a fantastic set (Kirkland brand) for less than $200, a fraction of what you'd pay separately for pans of that quality. To be honest, I've become a fanatic too. I'm pretty upset that we need to scrutinize our purchases for ingredients that have been banned in other parts of thr world for years. I think about the millions of young girls who walk into pharmacies and buy makeup that is possibly leading them down this road that we are on and get sad and angry. I guess that it's up to us to support  organizations who are trying to pass the word and force the FDA and EPA to act.

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2012 06:25AM ckk wrote: Annie, I am struggling with the balance issue, too. I'm now a two-time cancer survivor (melanoma was no 1), and I wasn't a sun worshiper, either. I've come to the tentative conclusion that there are some of us unlucky ones whose genetic makeup makes us vulnerable to cancer - whether it be through exposure to toxins, or to certain ingredients, or pollution, or whatever. Our cells are told to mutate and then we get cancer. After this episode and the turmoil and suffering it has caused, I have decided that I can't take a laid back attitude anymore. I guess that it makes me feel better to become as informed as possible, to feel as though I have some power to change or avoid future serious health problems. I know that there's no guarantee, but the fact of the matter is that it's my own self-advocacy that saved my life twice - both cancers were found by me by self exam. My MO told me last week after I asked that because of my dense tissue, my 1.6 cm tumor would probably not have been found on mammogram for another 2-3 years. So I feel like there's no choice going forward - be diligent, stay informed, and try to beat the odds. That's my 2 cents, anyway :-)

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2012 10:27PM ckk wrote: Deb, I'll echo what Wave said...it's important for us to help each other by spreading the word about whatever we come across. There's such power in the information that we share with one another, and thank you for posting. I have an MO appointment today and will ask about it. Wave, I know what you mean about feeling apart and distant from others. I think that it will always be like that in varying degrees. But here's the thing - there's so many cancer survivors out there that you don't know about. After my first infusion I came down with strep during my low period and landed in the ER. My nurse, and the guy who drew my blood were both recent cancer survivors (nurse had BC) and had undergone lots of chemo. I never would have known this if I hadn't had to tell them my story, and then of course we connected on a much different level, almost like long-lost relatives, people who KNEW.  It was comforting to talk to them, and they spent lots more time with me because of it (in fact at one point, someone came in to look for the guy taking blood and asked if we were having a party in my exam room, lol) . So that made me decide to not keep the knowledge of my cancer from others, because I do think that it makes me feel more alone if people don't know. Like you said, there's comfort in being with others who "get it". Rachel & Robin, I've been worried about raw cuticles and cracking hands too. My hands are always dry and they do crack, plus the anti bac gels are very drying. I am always wearing bandaids. heatherb, I laughed at the days left comment too! Too funny. I am in a bit of quandary. I realized last week that I need to start moving away from feeling like a sick person, so I asked my H to not assume that he would go to every appointment with me. Before BC, he never came with me to any dr appointment, and I am very private and independent. He was pretty offended when I tried to gently explain to him that I need to move away from cancer patient status and feel more independent, more like "me", so in the future if I needed him there, I would tell him. I realize that he was trying to be supportive, but at this point, it just feels like I'm being treated like a sick child. Now I feel guilty. Anyone else have this going on?

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2012 11:23PM ckk wrote: Good morning all! I had my nadir appt yesterday with the MO. For the first time, I felt like a "graduate". What a good feeling, so liberating! I asked her about the taxotere situation, and she had not heard anything, but said that she would research and talk to me about it next week (I see her after my BMRI). She thought that my phlebitis looked like classic phlebitis from T, and that in her observation, almost every patient runs into phlebitis from it. So, we'll see if she finds out anything. I will see her next week after my baseline BMRI, and then not again until after radiation in May. She wants me to get a bone density test before starting Tamox. I will be having bloodwork every 3 months to test for various things over the next three years. She's setting me up with the Lymphedema specialist to do a baseline exam and fit me for a sleeve for travel, and yes, she has seen women with as few as one or two nodes removed develop LE, and believes in being proactive. She said that it would take "at least a month" for the fatigue to resolve and a year for the phlebitis marks to fade, and said that exercise is the best weapon against the fatigue.As for the water retention, she thought that it would resolve over the next few weeks. Wave, I'm with you on wanting to get my independence back. It will make a big difference in my moving forward. Can I send my H to the Bahamas with yours? :-) Rachel, my lashes are about 1/2 gone, and I see little tiny new ones coming in. I gave up mascara, but I find that black powder eyeshadow applied like eyeliner to the lash line covers the missing lashes and looks pretty good. Hope everyone is has a great day! I go for my rads mapping in a couple of hours..whoo!

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2012 01:54AM ckk wrote: Karmil, again don't know how this impacts a different situation, but I was told no water warmer than body temp on my scalp, and the cooler the better. I have avoided the whole situation by taking baths instead of showers, and washing my hair at the kitchen sink with the hose attachment twice/week with cool water. I know that many women take a shower without putting their heads under, and then turn the water temp down to do the hair at the end. Another tip: in case you haven't already, avoid aluminum containing products such as deodorants because aluminum collects in the hair follicles. Only use sulfate-free shampoos as sulfates are very hard on the follicles too.

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2012 08:08AM ckk wrote: Good morning all, Rachel, sincere congrats that you're DONE! What a crappy way to end the ordeal, but at least you don't have to go back. It sounds like everything was conspiring to make the most challenging day possible for you. I had a reaction to Tax on my first tx, and because of that, each tx after that was run more slowly. I'm glad that your reaction was at the end of your treatment cycle. As for the tingling, you may want to consider going to acupuncture to resolve that quickly. My AC also gave me a B12 shot after every tx, and it really helped. My neuropathy symptoms resolved, and now I have none. I hope that you have an easy week ahead, and they're your last ones after chemo! YAY! Leesa, it sounds like you have lots of questions and concerns, and they should be answered. I am going every 3 months (with bloodwork) for the next two years, and getting scans of some sort every 6 months. It's crazy how different MOs can be! If you are not comfortable with the level of follow up, I would consider changing MOs. Your peace of mind is far more important than anything else, and the fear is not pleasant to live with! Momof3, so sorry to hear about your Aunt. It sounds like she slipped through the cracks of the system. It really drives home how we must all be our own advocates and demand the level of care that we are comfortable with. Gracie, I hope that you're feeling good and pain-free today. Karmil, glad the girls are looking good! I did not read that book, but I can tell you that cleaning my closets has been very cathartic! My H is a bit bewildered by the the garage full of trash bags that grows every day, lol. I am feeling pretty good over the last couple of days. I find that if I drink a cup of coffee late afternoon, my energy level picks back up. I have been able to ramp up my weight training to 3x/week, and I am now back to pre-surgery weights. My goal is to get my strength and endurance back to full speed by the end of the summer, and do a bike race in August. As soon as the weather gets warm here again, I will be out on the road training. In the process, I'm hoping to shed the rest of this excess weight.  Have a great day, everyone!

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2012 03:31AM ckk wrote: Hi all! Welcome to the Canadian ladies! I got the word about supplements - no extra Vitamins C&E, because they apparently can interfere with the radiation's efficacy. Now that that's settled, why didn't someone tell me that in the beginning? What would have happened if I had not asked? Anyway, I met with a dietitian at the center yesterday - it;s apparently a service offered to everyone in treatment at the rad center. She looked over my food diary (I use the Lose It app), and suggested a few things. Some interesting nuggets: No more than 25% protein in the diet, because the kidneys are still recovering from chemo; Soy as food is okay (tofu, edamame etc), but no soy protein powder; soybean oil based vitamins are ok; I should start taking 1000mg of Omega 3 every day for the anti inflammatory effects. The center is starting a nutrition support/weight loss group for people in treatment, so I signed up. I'm starting to get a little pink from the rads, and I'm a bit tired, but otherwise ok. Jen, I've been using Latisse for 6 weeks, and I definitely can see a difference in my lashes. My brows are starting to fill in now, too. I hope that you're better today. Rachel, glad that you got through the interview okay! Take it easy, and get your rest. Wave, which gel are you using? Momof3, I agree with you - if more men got BC, we'd probably have a vaccine by now, and we certainly wouldn't be making it a political issue. I am SO SICK of women's health becoming a political issue.  Have a great day all!
